The Consumer Rights Act 2015 will make it far easier for groups of consumers to seek compensation from firms that have fixed prices and formed cartels. It introduces a new "opt-out" collective action regime, which will allow consumer groups to bring claims on behalf of a whole class of affected consumers, without the need for each individual to actively join the lawsuit.

This is a significant change from the previous "opt-in" system, where consumers had to actively sign up to be part of a collective action. Under the new regime, consumers will be automatically included in the claim unless they specifically choose to opt-out. This will make it much simpler for consumers to seek redress, as they no longer have to take the initiative to join the lawsuit.

The Act also introduces a new power for the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to apply for a "redress order" on behalf of consumers who have been harmed by anti-competitive behavior. This will allow the CMA to directly compensate affected consumers, without the need for a separate court case.
